SEARCH
Module org.klojang.jdbc
Package org.klojang.jdbc

Interface ResultSetBeanifier<T>

Type Parameters:
T - the type of the JavaBeans produced by the ResultSetBeanifier
All Superinterfaces:
Iterable<T>
public sealed interface ResultSetBeanifier<T> extends Iterable<T>

Converts the rows in a JDBC ResultSet into JavaBeans or records. Instances are obtained via BeanifierFactory.getBeanifier().

Contrary to the SQLQuery class, a ResultSetBeanifier is agnostic about, and has no opinion on where you got the ResultSet from. In that sense it is closer to the JDBC metal than the SQLQuery class. It certainly does not pretend to be an ORM-like class. It just converts result sets into (flat) JavaBeans, to be carried across the boundary of the data access module (and into the view layer). The JavaBeans may have nested structures, but only top-level properties will be populated.

ResultSetBeanifier is an extension of the Iterable interface, enabling you to conveniently extract the JavaBeans in a forEach loop: 


 ResultSet rs = ...;
 BeanifierFactory factory = new BeanifierFactory(Employee.class);
 for(Employee emp : factory.getBeanifier(rs)) {
   // do stuff ...
 }

JavaBeans vs. Records

When converting a row to a JavaBean, a ResultSetBeanifier will always use the setters on the JavaBean to populate it. There is no way to populate the bean via its constructors. When converting to a record, a ResultSetBeanifier will obviously always use one of its constructors to populate it (since records don't have setters). Make sure the record has a constructor for those record components that map to columns in the SELECT clause. Also, the encounter order of the record components within the constructor must match the encounter order of the corresponding columns in the SELECT clause. They don't need to pair-wise line up, though. Not all record components must be mappable to columns in the SELECT clause and not columns in the SELECT clause must be mappable to record components.
Author:
Ayco Holleman

  • Method Details

    • beanify

      Optional<T> beanify()
      Converts the current row within the ResultSet into a JavaBean. If the ResultSet is empty, or if there are no more rows in the ResultSet, an empty Optional is returned. You can keep calling beanify() to successively extract all rows in the result set.
      Returns:
      an Optional containing the JavaBean or an empty Optional if the ResultSet contained no (more) rows

    • beanify

      List<T> beanify(int limit)
      Converts at most limit rows from the ResultSet into JavaBeans. If the ResultSet is empty, an empty List is returned.
      Parameters:
      limit - the maximum number of rows to extract and convert
      Returns:
      a List of JavaBeans or an empty List if the ResultSet contained no (more) rows

    • beanifyAll

      List<T> beanifyAll()
      Converts all remaining rows in the ResultSet into JavaBeans.
      Returns:
      a List of JavaBeans or an empty List if the ResultSet contained no (more) rows

    • beanifyAll

      List<T> beanifyAll(int sizeEstimate)
      Converts all remaining rows in the ResultSet into JavaBeans.
      Parameters:
      sizeEstimate - an estimate of the size of the resulting List.
      Returns:
      a List of JavaBeans or an empty List if the ResultSet contained no (more) rows

    • isEmpty

      boolean isEmpty()
      Returns true if the end of the ResultSet has been reached; false otherwise.
      Returns:
      whether the end of the ResultSet has been reached
